# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

# Solution

```julia
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter the DataFrame to only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_filtered = filter((row) -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` with value true for all rows
    df_filtered[:audi_a4_type] .= true
    
    # Return the resulting DataFrame
    return df_filtered
end

# Example usage:
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

# Call the function with the given DataFrame
result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```

The resulting `DataFrame`, `result`, will contain only the rows from `df_cars` where the manufacturer is "audi" and the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Additionally, it will have a new column named `audi_a4_type` with a value of `true` for all rows in the filtered DataFrame.
